THE COMPLAINT.  PART I.</br>Attend all ye nymphs of the plain,</br>'Tis beauty inspires my song,</br>'Tis beauty I sigh for in vain,</br>With sorrow these notes that prolong.
Thro' divers wild mazes I tread</br>Where Nature's rich bounty profuse</br>Throws flow'rs o'er hill and o'er mead,</br>And streams in meanders that flows.
Yet there no delight can bestow,</br>Nor gild the soft moments that glide</br>Tho' gentle the zephyrs that blow,</br>Along the sweet banks of the Bride.
For by a fair fountain reclined;</br>Whose streams in soft cadence run by</br>Ariana enraptur'd my mind,</br>And caus'd me incessant to sigh.
The bright painted ensigns of morn,</br>Whose splendors embroider the East</br>Still ever rise on me forlorn,</br>Still ever find me sore distrest.
Love beams from her sweet sparkling eyes!</br>Is cent'red within her soft breast!</br>As you view her new beauties arise,</br>Appear in gay order confest!
Her voice! — It is music to hear,</br>Such softness! — it dwells on her tongue,</br>Enraptur'd by it, I draw near</br>So sweet!  so harmonious her song!
How oft' in fond fancy reclin'd,</br>In vision my charmer I see,</br>But alas!  'tis delusion I find,</br>No perfect enjoyment for me.
So transient the fancied delight,</br>So frequent that visits in sleep,</br>So short the deceptions of night,</br>That leaves us awake but to weep.
Ah!  Philomel tune the dear strain,</br>Which Fancy and Love can inspire;</br>While night cloaths in russet the plain,</br>And Phoebus bright blushes retire.
And tell the dear maid that a swain,</br>Never lov'd more sincere nor more true,</br>And tell her his anguish and pain,</br>Is equall'd on earth but by few.
And tell her, for her he must die,</br>So melt all her soul into love,</br>In notes that may ring thro' the sky,</br>And make all harmonious the grove.
And if, when my suit you prefer,</br>A tear of soft pity shou'd flow;</br>And that she'd give ear to my pray'r,</br>What joy in my bosom wou'd glow.
Just like the glad hours that bring,</br>The fresh rising gales of the morn,</br>And like the sweet blossoms of spring,</br>The face of all Nature adorn.
My moments all tranquil wou'd glide</br>So smooth — !  Oh so sweet they would flow</br>No shepherd so happy beside,</br>As I thus so favour'd wou'd know.
Our flocks — then would vie with the snow,</br>Our fields — wou'd float over with corn,</br>Our rivers with silver should glow;</br>And violets the meadows adorn!
No shepherd like Strephon be found;</br>So constant, so faithful, so true,</br>For her whom the graces surround,</br>Shou'd bless him with raptures still new.
</br>FEAR.  PART II.</br>Engrav'd by the pencil of love,</br>Her image's impress'd on my mind,</br>Ah wou'd she so tender might prove,</br>As faithful sincere and as kind!
But I fear that the Fates will deny,</br>A blessing so great to my flame,</br>And hopeless still leave me to sigh,</br>Invoking in sleep her dear name.—
Lately I trip'd over the green,</br>And wandered in sorrow away,</br>Where others more social were seen,</br>In the calm closing hour of day.
With them — Oh how chearful and free!</br>The hours unminded pass'd o'er</br>But languid and tedious with me,</br>For pleasure with me is no more.
A train of fair damsels draw nigh,</br>With shepherds along the green glade,</br>They stop'd, — and they ask'd me for why,</br>So lonesome I sought the deep shade?
See Nature they say'd, all around,</br>How lavish!  how rich her array,</br>How sweet!  On how pleasing the sound</br>Of linnets that sing on each spray!
So sweet blows the Eglantine bow'r!</br>So sweet is the roses in bloom!</br>So mild, so refreshing each show'r,</br>That heightens their fragrant perfume!
Must love then so absolute reign,</br>To riffle the blossoms of peace,</br>And is there no nymph of the plain,</br>That equals Ariana in grace?
'Tis true I replied the gay scene,</br>With pleasures unnumber'd abound,</br>And chearful contentment is seen,</br>To tread in gay mazes around.
Of nymphs of the plain there may be,</br>That equal Ariana in mien,</br>But none has such charms for me,</br>Of all the fair maids of the green.
An outcast alone sure am I,</br>No friend to take part in my grief,</br>But lonesome I wander and sigh,</br>None pities or grants me relief.
They sneer and they laugh at my woe,</br>Despis'd and forsaken the while,</br>Amidst their gay circles ne'er go,</br>Nor even am bless'd with a smile.
How then shall I hope to obtain,</br>The girl that I love and admire,</br>Since scorned by all the gay train,</br>Rejected I'm forced to retire.
So in that deep thicket and shade,</br>Immur'd and forgotten I'll lie,</br>And still ever love the dear maid,</br>For whom I must languish and die.
</br>SOLITUDE.  PART III.</br>Then witness, ye shady deep grove,</br>To whose gloomy coverts I fly,</br>That Ariana alone is my love,</br>For whom I must languish and die.
Ere the bright rising blushes appear,</br>Diffus'd o'er the face of the morn,</br>To yonder deep grott will repair,</br>All shades and covered with thorn.
There pensive and lonely remain,</br>There my vows and devotions will pay</br>Till night shall extend her domain,</br>And spread o'er with darkness the day.
With my tears I will water the ground,</br>While nightingales warble their loves,</br>While mists and dark vapours surround,</br>And deepen with horror the groves.
Beneath some old willow reclin'd.</br>Whose branches hang mournfully down,</br>I'll sit and will ponder in mind,</br>Those hours of bliss that are flown.
My pipe on the branches that hung,</br>No more will with Hyacinths dress,</br>But wreath'd all in Cypress the song</br>Of my love for Ariana rehearse.
To the valleys around will proclaim,</br>What charms in her person appear,</br>And often invoke her dear name;</br>By the tender addition of "dear."
Each softest expression which love,</br>In all its extream can express,</br>Shall constant resound thro' the grove;</br>And mournful flow thro' my verse.
The thickets shall closer intwine,</br>To wrap me within their deep shade</br>And its closest recesses be mine,</br>Until I obtain my dear maid.
No more the fresh fountains and flow'rs,</br>That lately allur'd me to roam,</br>The grotto's, cascades and green bow'rs,</br>Mark the spot that so late was my home.
But gloomy surrounded by shade,</br>In this lonesome wild far away;</br>No more their blest tracts shall I tread</br>Or spend in sweet labour the day.
No more shall my fair fleecy care,</br>Around me so sportingly play,</br>Nor the flow'rs industry did rear,</br>Expand their sweet blooms to the day.
Uncultur'd neglected they lie,</br>All wither'd quite faded and gone,</br>Whose odours perfumed all the sky,</br>Are now all abandon'd and flown.
What anguish!  what pain must be mine,</br>If ever I visit them more,</br>To see that fair garden declin'd,</br>That lately so flourish'd before.
But if my dear fair shou'd appear,</br>The lilies and roses wou'd bloom,</br>Expand all their leaves to the air,</br>And spread far and wide their perfume.
Like Spring her gay presence wou'd be,</br>Her eyes wou'd revive the sweet scene,</br>So joyous the fair one to see,</br>The lambkins wou'd skip o'er the green.
Her absence like some cruel blast,</br>Has nip all the blossoms away,</br>O may she return at last</br>And chear with her presence like May.
</br>THE FAREWELL.  PART IV.</br>Adieu, ye sweet cottage and bow'r,</br>How blest was your humble retreat!</br>Contented I spent ev'ry hour,</br>With lambkins that play'd at my feet.
Soft echo I talk'd with, the while,</br>That faithful re-answer'd my song,</br>While peace so serene with a smile,</br>Attended my footsteps along.
How oft by the clear river side,</br>So tired I sunk to repose;</br>Its streams in soft cadence did glide,</br>Refreshing the banks as it flows.
These joys ne'er again I shall know,</br>The innocent pastime is o'er,</br>Yon stream from its fountains shall flow,</br>But back again wander no more.
Ye nymphs and ye swains now adieu,</br>Abandon'd and lonesome I fly:</br>For now there's no comfort with you;</br>Since my dear Ariana's not nigh.
Before I had known the dear maid,</br>Your presence drove sorrow away,</br>When e'er we convers'd in the shade,</br>Or walk'd in the cool of the day.
The first infant blossoms of Spring,</br>I'd crop and wou'd lay at her feet,</br>Each bird as a present wou'd bring,</br>Whose note was harmonious and sweet.
The pleasure I've sought for in vain,</br>These presents my love shou'd approve</br>And kindly attend to the strain,</br>I'd sing in her praise through the grove.
But Fortune a foe to my bliss,</br>Has sunk me below her esteem,</br>And what I've lost besides this,</br>The peace that I ne'er can redeem.
In vain shall the season appear,</br>That cloaths all the landskip in green,</br>To chear with its presence the year,</br>And robe in new beauty the plain.
The larks in the morn shall arise,</br>The groves as harmonious shall be:</br>Their music delight and surprize,</br>But these have no charms for me.
If Ariana refuses to smile,</br>All then is a desart around,</br>No more shall the seasons beguile</br>Or music breathe rapture around.</br>
